She has four children and she is supporting their education. She wants all of her children to succeed in their studies so that when they are older, they can find better employment and support the needs of their future families.

She chose CEVI because it has an insurance coverage package for all of its clients. She applied for a loan of 4,000 PHP which she will use to buy farm supplies and more used clothes to sell.

loans.use: to purchase farm supplies and clothes to sell

loans.name: Mehrullo

texts.en:
Mehrullo, a farmer, lives with his family, comprised of his wife, two children and parents. His father helps him in the care of their land. In the past they have had problems in harvesting, forcing them to sell their crop in advance, thereby resulting in reduced earnings. Mehrullo has subsequently gained much business experience and now his crop is one of the most demanded at the market. Because his field is infertile, he has decided to request a loan to buy seed, fertilizer, fuels and lubricants to support the field and make his crop more productive.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes its role as a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need.

To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: Purchasing seed, fertilizer, fuels and lubricants

loans.name: Ara

texts.en: Ara P. had been working abroad for several years. After saving some money, he returned to his homeland and invested in a trade business. He proved to be a successful businessman and a very client-oriented entrepreneur. Ara regularly updates his clothing stock, and has applied for this loan for that purpose.

loans.use: To purchase new clothing inventory.

loans.name: Nenita

texts.en:
Nenita B. is from the village of Nagrumbuan, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 57 years old. Nenita is married and has 2 adult-aged children. To make a living, Nenita owns & operates a business venture in the retail sector running a general store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Nenita has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 2500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Nenita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nenita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 6000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Nenita is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. This loan will be the 4th loan taken out by Nenita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 38 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional inventory & working capital

loans.name: Lolo Group

texts.fr:
Lolo est un regroupement de 4 femmes ayant en moyenne 32  ans, 3 enfants et vivant  dans des familles nucléaires à Filabougou, un des quartiers de la ville Ouelessebougou de Koulikoro (2ème région administrative du Mali). 
Elles sont à leur première collaboration avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce de pagnes avec BAOU G., d’habits pour enfants et des produits alimentaires.
Elle compte acheter avec son  prêt,  12 pièces de pagnes wax. Elle s’approvisionne au grand marché  de Bamako (capitale du Mali) auprès des grossistes. Ellle effectue sa vente au  marché de Ouelessebougou et à domicile à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes, en détail, au comptant et à crédit. 
Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 20.000.FCFA dont une partie sera utilisée  pour l’appui de son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes et l’autre partie sera investie dans les activités.
texts.en:
Lolo is a group of 4 women who are, on average, 32 years old, have three children, and live in nuclear families in Filabougou, a district in the city of Ouelessebougou, in Koulikoro, (2nd administrative region of Mali).

They are on their first joint loan with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso because they want to be able to meet the demands of their clientele.  This group of women sells pagnes (lengths of brightly colored cloth used for clothing), children’s clothing, and food products, as does Baou G..

With her loan, she plans to buy 12 Wax pagnes.  She gets her supplies at the main market in Bamako, the capital of Mali, from wholesalers.  She makes her sales at retail at the market in Ouelessebougou and door to door to a clientele made up mostly of women, for cash and on credit. 

She foresees making an average monthly profit of 20,000 FCFA, a part of which will be used to help her husband with daily expenses and the rest will be invested in her business.

loans.use: to buy Wax pagnes

loans.name: Ama

texts.en: Ama A. sells provisions, food items, and soap at Abbrem Agona near Abra, Cape Coast. She is married and has five dependants. Her husband is a farmer. Ama has been selling food items for four years. She assists her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy other varieties of food items for resale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to reinvest back into her business.

loans.use: To buy food items for resale

loans.name: Lun

texts.en: Lun S., 22, resides with her family in Siem Reap province, Cambodia, an area known for Angkorean temples. S. is a traditional Apsara dancer, earning an income of USD 2.5 per day. Her husband is a chef, earning an income of USD 5 per day. Each month, the family has to spend USD 43 on food and USD 25 on other necessary expenses. Lun is requesting a loan of USD 1200 to purchase a motorbike for the family's use. In the future, she would like to use any additional income to repair her house. This will be her first loan from CREDIT, a long standing Kiva partner.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for family use

loans.name: Las Olivo Group

texts.es: Este grupo solidario se llama Las Olivo, se encuentra ubicado en la comunidad de Moyotepec, Ayala, en el estado de Morelos, México, está integrado por 4 mujeres que se conocen y son vecinas, ellas son la señora Lorenza E. C. va a comprar con su préstamo arroz por kilo, huevo, carne de puerco, salchichas, verduras, crema, quesos, maíz para preparar sus alimentos, la señora Marlen Catalina V. Vázquez va a comprar zapatos para dama, caballero y niño por pedido y par tener que ofrecerle a sus clientes, la señora Agustina C. R. va a comprar mercancía servilletas y manteles de tela, hilos, agujas, botones, resorte, sierres, ganchos etc. Para surtir su negocio, la señora Melba Alicia García Q. va a comprar ropa blusas, faldas, pantalones, suéteres, ropa para caballero pantalones y camisas. La señora Agustina C. R. es integrante del grupo, ella tiene 57 años de edad estudio hasta el 6º. Año de primaria, ella es casada su esposo es campesino tienen 6 hijos Porfirio tiene 42 años de edad, Ezequiel tiene 40 años de edad, Jesús tiene 38 años de edad, Héctor tiene 35 años de edad, Germán tiene 32 años de edad y Luis tiene 30 años de edad todos sus hijos son casados y trabajan, ella tiene su negocio de mercería, juguetería y artículos para mujer perfumes, cosméticos y adornos para las mujeres, ella solicito su préstamo para comprar mercería va a comprar hilos, agujas, estambres, aros, servilletas y manteles para bordar y juguetes, sus clientes son las muchacha y las señoras, ella les ofrece artículos de mercería como son servilletas para bordar, hilos estambres, aros para bordar, cosméticos, perfumes juguetes y artículos para arreglo de niñas y muchachas pasadores, prendedores, bolitas etc. Su negocio lo inicio hace 20 años por necesidad para sacar a sus hijos adelante, ella aprendió solita a ira a la Cd. De México, por su mercancía, ella empezó de poquito, no gastaba puro invertir todo lo que vendía lo volvía a invertir  y fue creciendo poco a poco, ahorita ya tiene ganancias, ella se fue a trabajar 2 años y medio a los Estados Unidos y fue guardando y cuando regreso hizo la casilla de su negocio ya puede dejar su mercancía porque antes la llevaba y la traía también pudo volver a surtir de mercancía y creció más su negocio, el puesto donde tiene su negocio es prestado esta en el mercado municipal de Moyotepec, esta a cuadra y media de su casa y llega caminando, su negocio es importante porque le ayuda a sobrevivir, le sirve para ocupar su tiempo, le entretiene y a la vez le ayuda, cuando está en su negocio está trabajando haciendo arreglos en fieltro le está enseñando una amiga, ella está orgullosa de su negocio gracias a Dios y al esfuerzo que le ha puesto está orgullosa de tener este tipo de negocio, su esposo le ayuda en el negocio le ayuda a atender a los clientes y a poner el puesto, su negocio es popular por la ubicación en el mercado y vienen varias personas a comprar, los desafíos que enfrenta su negocio son los costos elevados porque se ve en la necesidad de que si esta caro le sube el precio al producto, su negocio enfrenta la competencia de otro negocio igual en el mercado, las ganancias de su negocio las utiliza en lo que necesita, en el gas, la luz a veces el teléfono y para volver a invertir, lo que gasta son las ganancias, tiene su inversión ya aparte. La señora Agustina está muy contenta con este préstamo porque le dan la oportunidad de surtir su negocio, realizarse y agrandarlo para que se vea más bonito, este  negocio le ha ayudado mucho económicamente, las mejoras que desea hacer a su vivienda son agrandar hacer mas recamaras para cuando sus hijos vengan de visita con su familia tengan donde llegar, sus planes y esperanza son seguir prosperando en su negocio e ir ahorrando para cuando no pueda trabajar, sus hijos ya ven por sus necesidades son mayores y son suficientes para sus hogares. Las integrantes del grupo quieren decir a  Kiva y a Fundación Realidad “Gracias por el apoyo que nos dan, nos sentimos a gusto ya que están interesados en nuestros negocio y más que nada que las mujeres se superen y nos ayudan mucho por el bajo interés que nos dan, que cobren menos interés, muchas gracias por su ayuda que nos va ser de gran ayuda”.
texts.en:
This communal bank is called “Las Olivo” and is located in the community of Moyotepec, Ayala in the Mexican state of Morelos.  Four women are its members; they all know each other and are neighbors.  They are:  Mrs. Lorenza E. C. who will use the loan to buy rice by the kilogram, eggs, pork, sausages, vegetables, cream, cheese and corn to prepare her meals; Mrs. Marlen Catalina V. Vázquez who will buy women’s, men’s and children’s shoes on order and to have stock available to offer her customers; Mrs. Agustina C. R. who will buy merchandise like cloth napkins and tablecloths and thread, needles, buttons, elastic, clasps, hooks, etc.; to stock her business, Mrs. Melba García Q. will buy blouses, skirts, pants, sweaters and men’s clothes like pants and shirts.

Mrs. Agustina C. R. is a group member.  She’s 57 years old and finished sixth grade of elementary school.  She’s married and her husband’s a farmer; they have six children:  Porfirio, 42, Ezequiel, 40, Jesús, 38, Héctor, 35, Germán, 32 and Luis, 30.  All the children are married and work.  

She has a business selling notions, toys and women’s articles like perfume, cosmetics and accessories.  She requested her loan to buy merchandise.  She will buy thread, needles, yarn, hoops, napkins and tablecloths to embroider and toys.  Her usual customers are young girls and women.  She offers them notions like napkins to embroider, thread, yarn, embroidery hoops, cosmetics, perfumes, toys and accessories for young girls and young ladies like hairpins, brackets, pendants, etc.  

She started her business 20 years ago needing to support her children.  She taught herself how to go to Mexico City on her own to get her merchandise.  She started out with just a few items.  She wouldn’t spend anything but rather would reinvest all her profits back into the business.  She gradually grew and now she earns profits.

She went to work in the United States for two and a half years and saved up.  When she returned she built her business’ booth so now is able to leave her merchandise there because before she had to take it back and forth from home.  She was also able to vary her merchandise and her business grew still more.  The space where she has her booth is borrowed and is in the town of Moyotepec a block and a half from home; she can walk to it.

Her business is important because it helps her survive, it helps her fill her time and it amuses her while helping her.  When she’s at work she is also working making felt arrangements that a friend is teaching her how to make.  She is proud of her business.  Thanks to God and the effort she’s put into it she is proud to have this kind of business.

Her husband helps her take care of customers and to set up the booth.  Her business is popular because of its location in the market and several people come by to buy.  The challenges she faces are the high costs because if the price of her products rises she has to raise her prices too.  Her business faces competition from another similar one in the market.

She uses profits from the business to cover needs like gas, light and sometimes the telephone and to reinvest.  What she likes are the profits; she has a separate investment already.

Agustina is very happy with this loan because it allows her to stock her business, to become fulfilled and to enlarge it so that it will look prettier.  This business has helped her economically quite a bit.

She’d like to make some home improvements like enlarge some of the bedrooms so that when her children visit with their families they’ll have somewhere to stay.  Her plans and hopes are to continue progressing in her business and continue to save for when she is unable to work any longer.  Her children are adult and take care of their own households.

The group members want to say to Kiva and to Fundación Realidad:  “Thanks for the support you give us.  We feel good because you are interested in our businesses and, above all, that women better themselves.  You help us a lot with the low interest rates you offer, by charging less interest.  Thank you very much for the support which will be of great help to us.

loans.use: to buy merchandise like thread, needles, yarn and embroidery hoops to embroider napkins and tablecloths and to buy toys.

loans.name: San Bartolo Group

texts.es:
Doña Rosario T. Y., es una señora casada, tiene 41 años D. edad, tiene 5 hijos y estudian, no tuvo la oportunidad D. estudiar, es ama D. casa, pero se dedica a la crianza D. animales, en este caso pollos, cuenta con 2 años D. experiencia. 

DeciD. organizar un grupo con el fin D. solicitar un préstamos para comprar mas pollos, las integrantes D. este grupo se dedican a diversas actividades: crianza D. animales y la venta D. tomates, esperan que con el préstamo que solocitan mejorar su negocio y su condicion D. vida, quieren ver su negocio en el futuro con muchos animales y mejores ganancias.
texts.en:
Rosario T. Y. is 41 years old and married.  She has five children who are students.  She herself did not have the opportunity to be a student.  She is a housewife and works as an animal breeder, in this case chickens.  She has two years' experience.

Rosario organized a group with the goal of requesting funds to buy more chickens.  The members of this group work in different occupations such as animal breeding and tomato sales.  They hope that with the loan they are seeking they can improve their respective businesses and quality of life.  They envision owning many animals and having better earnings in the future.

loans.use: to buy some chickens for breeding

loans.name: Alba Marina

texts.es: Alba Marina F. D. V. vive con su esposo y sus tres hijos en el departamento D. La Unión, Ella posee un negocio, una sala D. belleza ubicada en el centro D. La Unión un lugar muy concurrido por la gente. Alba es toda una madre D. familia y una trabajadora entregada a su labor siempre está dispuesta a mejorar, su sala D. belleza es muy conocida en el lugar pues ella tiene el mejor servicio y realiza los mejores cortes D. cabello, sus clientes no la cambian y últimamente ha sido más solicitada por otras personas y necesita más productos con que realizar su trabajo y es por eso que le solicita a INTEGRAL un crédito que le permita comprar materiales como shampo, acondicionador, tijeras, vitaminas para el cabello, esmaltes, entres otros y así mantener su calidad D. trabajo. Esta es la forma en que Alba se gana el pan D. cada día y como sostiene su hogar y espera que en un futuro se expanda mas para así lograr todas sus metas.
texts.en: Alba Marina F. D. V. lives with her husband and three children in the departament of La Unión, She has a business, a beauty shop located in the center of  La Unión, a place where a lot of people congregate. Alba is a complete wife and mother and a hardworker dedicated to her job. She is always willing to improve and her beauty salon is very well known in the area. She has the best service and does the best haircuts. Her customers won't leave her and lately she has been sought after by other people and needs more products to do her work. That is why she is asking INTEGRAL for a loan that will allow her to buy materials such as shampoo, conditioner, scissors, hair vitamins, and nail polish among other things. This will allow her to maintain the quality of her work. This is the way that Alba will earn her daily bread and support her home. She hopes that in the future she can expand more to be able to achieve her goals.

loans.use: to buy shampoo, conditioner, scissors, vitamins and nail polish.

loans.name: Ana Cary

texts.es:
Ana tiene 22 años de edad, es soltera y reside junto a su hijo en una zona rural de Saltur que se ubica en la localidad de Zaña, un distrito agrícola y ganadero que se encuentra situado en la región Lambayeque, a más de cuarenta minutos de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Se dedica a venta de chicha de jora fresca  y cerveza los ofrece a sus vecinos y personas que vienen a trabajar en la zona, esta actividad la realiza hace tres años. El negocio es de mucha ayuda para su familia, ya que por medio de esta se encarga de ayudar al sostenimiento de su economía diaria.

Ana desea ampliar su negocio con la compra de insumos para elaborar la chicha de jora y también comprar cerveza  ya que la zona donde se ubica su negocio es turística y puede incrementar sus ganancias. Por ello ha creído conveniente solicitar a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 800 nuevos soles con los cuales piensa lograr su objetivo.
texts.en:
Ana is 22 years old, single, and lives together with her son in a rural area of Saltur which is located in Zaña.  This is a district where people farm and raise livestock.  It is in Lambayeque region, more than forty minutes from the city of Chiclayo.

Ana sells fresh 'chicha de jora' (a corn-based drink) and beer to her neighbors and people who come to work in the area.  She has been in this business for three years.  Her business is a great help to her family since it allows her to help support them financially.

Ana would like to expand her business by purchasing supplies for making her chicha de jora.  She would also like to buy beer since the area where her business is located is a tourist area and she will be able to increase her profits.  For this reason, she has requested a loan for 800 Peruvian soles from Edpyme Alternativa which she plans to use to achieve her goal.

loans.use: to buy supplies to make her products

loans.name: Maria Sergia

texts.es: La señora María se dedica a la elaboración y venta D. comida desD. hace ocho años, dicha actividad lo realiza en su domicilio cuenta con buena clientela ya que cerca D. su domicilio están ubicadas varias fabricas y hay gran afluencia D. personas por dicha zona, vive en domicilio propio junto a su esposo y sus dos hijas quienes le colaboran en la elaboración y venta D. comida, solicita el crédito para la ampliación D. su local y para comprar mas insumos para la venta D. comida, es una persona muy trabajadora se levanta desD. muy tempranas horas para la elaboración D. su comida, esta gradecida con la institución por el apoyo brindado.
texts.en:
Maria has been making and selling food for eight years.  She does this at her home.  She has a good amount of customers because her home is near various factories.  There is a great influx of people in her area.

She lives with her husband and her two daughters.  They help make and sell the food.

She is requesting the loan to expand her site and to buy more supplies for her food sales.  She is a very hard-working person.  She gets up very early in order to make her food.  

She is grateful to the institution for they support they have provided.

loans.use: to expand her site and to buy more supplies to make food.

loans.name: Rafiq

texts.en:
Rafiq  is 45 years old, married and has five children. Due to his family’s financial situation, he did not have many opportunities to get higher education. That’s why, after finishing school, he tried to become independent and to find a way of earning in order to help his parents and now his own family.

Through the years, he tried various types of activities and finally he started his business selling cell phones. Since 2005, Rafiq has supported his family through his efforts. He believes that this business is profitable and the generated income allows him to support his family.

Currently, his business is doing well, but Rafiq needs to increase his stock of goods in order to serve the demands of his clientele. With this purpose in mind, Rafiq has requested  a loan of 1,300 AZN. 

He is grateful to all those supporting him and promises to repay the loan promptly.

loans.use: to purchase and diversify mobile phone inventories.

loans.name: Ajonjoli Group

texts.es: El grupo se llama “AJONJOLÍ” y se encuentra ubicado en el estado de Morelos en México. La mayoría de los habitantes se dedica a la elaboración de dulces típicos utilizando amaranto, cacahuate, semilla, tamarindo, entre otros, cabe mencionar la elaboración de obleas, la oblea es un postre típico de México, hecho con dos galletas dentro de las cuales hay dulce de leche, a menudo acompañada de leche condensada, chispas de chocolate, coco rallado, dulce de mora, queso o mermelada. Las galletas están hechas normalmente de harina de trigo, midiendo aproximadamente 20 centímetros de diámetro y 1 milímetro  de espesor, la cual es originaria de Huazulco puesto que fue la primera población que inició esta actividad, este producto es exportado a otros lugares. Una de las integrantes de este grupo es la señora LILIA la cual tiene un negocio de venta y producción de oblea, es una persona muy responsable y trabajadora quien desea invertir en su negocio para la mejora de su negocio y calidad de vida de su familia. Quiere este prestamo para comprar más materia prima para la elaboración de sus obleas como dulce, leche, galletas etc. una de sus metas más importantes es el lograr brindarles una carrera a sus hijos y lograr un posicionamiento a nivel nacional. En la foto se muestra las colchas que vende otra de las integrantes del grupo.
texts.en:
This group, called Ajonjoli, is located in the Mexican state of Morelos. Most of the people who live there earn their living making sweets that are typical of the region. To make them, they use amaranth, peanuts, seeds and tamarind, among other ingredients.

There are also sweets called obleas. Obleas are typical Mexican sweets consisting of two wafers with a dulce de leche filling. They often include condensed milk, pieces of chocolate, grated coconut, blackberry filling, cheese or jam. The wafers are usually made from wheat flour and measure approximately 20 centimeters across and 1 millimeter in thickness. Obleas originated in Huazulco since the inhabitants there were the first people to make these sweets. Obleas are exported to other places.

Lilia is one of the members of this group. She has a store where she makes and sells obleas. She is a very responsible, hardworking person. Lilia would like to invest in her store in order to improve it as well as her family's quality of life. She plans to use this loan to to purchase more ingredients such as jam, milk and wafers etc. to make obleas. One of her most important goals is to help her children find careers which will allow them to achieve recognition on a national level. In the photo, you can see the other members of the group holding up the bedspreads that they sell.

loans.use: to purchase more ingredients such as jam, milk and wafers to make obleas (Mexican sweets).

loans.name: Bridie

texts.es:
Bridie tiene 44 años de edad y vive con su hijo en Calle Real, barrio ubicado en la ciudad de Cartagena de Indias, una linda y colonial ciudad a orillas del mar caribe y frecuentemente visitada por turistas nacionales e internacionales que admiran su cálido escenario de gente amable y trabajadora. 
Desde hace 8 años Bridie vendia productos naturales para una empresa importante, pero su ímpetu emprendedor y deseo de ser independiente, primaron ante la alternativa de seguir siendo empleada o empresaria de su propia microempresa. Ella decidió emprender su aventura de negocio y tomó toda la experiencia de su antiguo trabajo y la tradujo en un negocio de venta de productos naturales en  punto comercial llamado “Tienda naturista Sol de Vida”. Con un ahorro que habia logrado, hizo su primera inversión y hasta la presente le ha ido muy bien, por eso esta entusiasmada y quiere fortalecerlo, hasta lograr un crecimiento que le ayude a aumentar sus ingresos y con ello incrementar el bienestar de su hijo hasta llevarlo a que obtenga estudios superiores y potencialice su éxito en la vida. Su credikiva es el primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, con el comprará  productos naturales como té verde, miel de abejas, quemadores de grasa, purgantes naturales entre otros. Su mayor desafio es el capital de trabajo pues no es suficiente en la medida en que se incrementan las ventas y requiere tener un efectivo disponible para surtir especialmente con los puctos que mas rotan.  Mientras Bridie construye su sueño a fuerza de trabajo y disciplina, continua esmerandose por sostener una rentabilidad sobre sus ventas no menor del 38% una rentabilidad sobre la inversiòn no menor de un 33%, para lograr su sostenibilidad.
texts.en:
Bridie is 44 years old and lives with her son in Calle Real, a neighborhood which is located in the city of Cartagena de Indias, a beautiful and colonial city on the shores of the Caribbean sea which is frequently visited by both domestic and international tourists who admire its warm scenery and its kind and hard-working people.

For eight years, Bridie sold natural products for a well-known company.  However, her entrepreneurial spirit and her desire to be her own boss prevailed over the alternative of continuing to work as an employee and she now works as a businesswoman in charge of her own microbusiness.  Bridie decided to undertake her own business venture.  She took advantage of all the experience she gained in her old job and started her own business selling natural products from a commercial sales location called "Tienda Naturista Sol de Vida".  With some savings that she had made, she made her first investment and, up to now, her business has done very well.  For this reason, she is enthusiastic and would like to strengthen her business and achieve a level of growth that will help her to increase her income and, thereby, improve the well-being of her son so that he can pursue a higher education and be successful in life.

This Kiva loan is Bridie's first loan with Fundación Mario Santo Domingo.  She will use it to buy natural products such as green tea, bees' honey, fat burners, natural laxatives, etc.  Her biggest challenge is working capital as she does not have enough.  As she increases her sales, she needs to have cash available to stock her business, especially with the products that have the quickest turnover.

While Bridie builds her dreams through her hard work and discipline, she continues to take care to maintain a profitability on her sales of no less than 38% and a profitability on her investment of no less than 33%, in order to achieve sustainability in her business.

loans.use: to buy natural products such as green tea, bees' honey, fat burners and natural laxatives

loans.name: Aisha

texts.en:
Aisha is married and has five children, all of whom are in school. She lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity but not to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees, rent and utility bills.

Aisha sells charcoal. She has done so for ten years, and she works seven days a week. Aisha sells her charcoal at retail prices from her home. She also sells tomatoes. The main business challenges for Aisha include thieves and tomato seasonality.

Aisha has requested a loan of 300,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of charcoal. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start going directly to villages for her charcoal and to sell at wholesale only.

loans.use: To buy more  bags of charcoal.

loans.name: Dionicio Francisco

texts.es:
Dionicio tiene una tienda de abarrotes donde también vende frutas y verduras, además de la tienda de abarrotes, Dionicio trabaja la carpintería desde hace 5 años. El esta pidiendo el préstamo para hacer mas grande  su carpintería.
Cuenta con un local grande pero lo que  mas necesita es material ya que  su inventario esta escaso .
El señor Dionicio siempre le a gustado  tener una carpintería  mas  grande para que sus hijos  le puedan ayudar y aprendan ya que les gusta un poco.
Además de la carpintería le gusta mucho atender su tienda de abarrotes ya que su esposa Luisa la ayuda en su carpintería .
Todos los fines de semana van a los pueblos vecinos  a vender sus mesas cosas necesarias para obtener mas ganancias  y comprar  mas material.
Esta muy contento por el apoyo que les  ha  dado su esposa en esto de pedir el préstamo para comprar mas material para hacer trabajos mas  grandes y a domicilio, ya que ella lo acompaña para que el trabajo sea mas rápido.
Le da las gracias a Fundación Realidad por el apoyo que les ha dado para salir adelante en su carpintería ya  que uno de sus mejores sueños es hacer  su carpintería  grande y con mas material para que sus clientes se sientan muy contentos y vuelva a su carpintería Luisa.
texts.en:
Dionicio has a grocery store which also sells fruits and vegetables.  In addition to the grocery store, Dionicio has been doing carpentry work for the last 5 years. He is asking for the loan to grow his carpentry shop.

He has a large space, but what he needs is more lumber as his inventory is low.  Señor Dionicio would always have liked a larger carpentry shop so his children are able to help him and learn and that they will enjoy it a bit.

In addition to carpentry he really likes to keep his grocery store stocked and his wife Luisa helps him with the carpentry.  Every weekend they go to neighboring towns to sell their tables and necessary items to get more profits and to buy more lumber.

He is very pleased by the support that his wife has given him, and is asking for this loan to buy more lumber to do larger jobs, and at home, as she accompanies him so that his work goes faster.

He thanks Fundación Realidad for the support given to him so that he can move ahead with his carpentry shop. as one of his biggest dreams is to to make his carpentry shop bigger and have more lumber so that his clients will be very happy and will return to his carpentry shop.

loans.use: to buy lumber for carpentry

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
Mary Ann, 31, is married with two children, aged three and eight. She is a farmer from the town of Banga, South Cotabato. Mary Ann has been growing rice for four years and also raises pigs in her backyard. She fattens the pigs and sells them at the market.

Mary Ann is requesting a loan to purchase fertilizer, herbicide and other farming supplies. She hopes to be able to send her two children to school and have them finish college in the future.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer, herbicide and other farming supplies.

loans.name: Sokheeang

texts.en: Sokheeang, 39 years old, is a worker with her husband. Their income is $8 per day. She has no children to stay with.  Every month, she has to spend $70 on food, $5 on electricity, and $10 on other expenses. She would like to request a loan of $1,000 to buy a motorbike to travel to work with her husband. She wants to sell grocery goods at home instead of working as a worker when she gets older and can make a better income than her current job.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for traveling to work with her husband

loans.name: Teymur

texts.en: Teymur, 33, owns a little grocery store in the local market where he sells a variety of goods. He works with his wife and they have 2 children to support. Teymur has asked for a loan of 1,500 AZN to purchase more grocery products in order to expand his options and increase his inventory. He believes that this will allow him to reach a wider customer base so he can increase his income to help provide for his family. This will be Teymur's second loan and he promises to repay it in a timely manner.

loans.use: to purchase more merchandise to increase profit

loans.name: Rosa

texts.es: Rosa tiene 37 años, vive en compañía de su hijo en casa de un familiar. Tiene 6 años de experiencia en la preparación y venta de pasteles, ya que tiene la ventaja de trabajar en una panadería por tanto tiene la facilidad de poder hornear sus pasteles. Es así que en sus horas libres, siendo las tardes se dedica a atender su puesto de ventas que tiene en su misma casa, o cuando puede reparte sus pasteles a otras tiendas pasteleras que le soliciten, pues le hacen pedidos de los postres que prepara. Disfruta de su trabajo cada día porque le encanta elaborar pasteles y considera que es un trabajo donde puede ejecutar todo su potencial y habilidad en la  decoración, ya que además es un producto muy cotizado generándole ganancias. Es la sexta oportunidad en la cual tiene un crédito con MFP de las cuales de siente muy satisfecha de ser una de las socios que tiene trayectoria limpia de trabaja en créditos  en las cuales ha demostrado ser puntual en sus pagos. En esta ocasión invertirá su crédito en la compra de materiales e ingredientes para  seguir preparando sus pasteles de diferentes sabores y texturas.
texts.en: Rosa is 37 years old and lives with her son in a relative's house. She has 6 years experience making and selling cakes. She has the advantage of being able to bake her cakes in a bakery as she works there. In her spare time, in the afternoons, she takes care of her cake-selling stall which is located in her house, or when she can, she delivers her cakes to other cake shops who order the desserts she makes. She enjoys her work every day as she loves making cakes and considers it a job where she can use her full potential and skills at decorating cakes as well as making a product that is in great demand and generates profits for her. This is the 6th time she has taken out a loan with MFP and is very happy to be one of the members who has a clean track record in handling loans and has proven to be punctual with her repayments.This time she will use the loan to buy products and ingredients to continue making her cakes of different flavours and textures.

loans.use: to buy products and consumables to make cakes.

loans.name: Enkhtsetseg

texts.en:
Mrs. Enkhtsetseg, 46, runs a grocery store selling basic food commodities. She lives with her three children and husband in her own house located in Choibalsan, a town in Dornod province. Her two daughters study at secondary school and the other is a college student. Her husband, Enkhbat, works as a watchman. 
Enkhtsetseg is a very hard worker. Initially, her business started as a food kiosk in 2001. She then expanded it into a small grocery store in 2006. Now she has a plan to expand or renovate her store into a shop that sells a larger variety of food. This will be very beneficial to her family income and a good way to improve her business. Therefore she is requesting a loan to purchase building materials to rebuild her store.

loans.use: to purchase some building materials to rebuild her store.

loans.name: Soadat

texts.ru: Соадат жительница района Шахритус. Ей 42 года. Она замужем. У нее четверо детей. Ее муж работает в дехканском хозяйстве. Сама она занимается посевом овощей и бахчевых культур. Этим видом деятельности она занимается 12 лет. Так как сейчас сезон посева лука, она берет кредит для закупа семян и топлива.
texts.en: Soadat lives in the Shahrituz district.  She is 42 years old, married and has four children.  Her husband works at a dekhan farm.  Soadat is involved in sowing vegetables and melons.  She has been in this business for 12 years.  Because now is the season to sow onions, she is requesting a loan to buy seeds and fuel.

loans.use: to buy seeds and fuel

loans.name: Anacleta

texts.en:
Anacleta works hard to support her family. Anacleta is married and has a fishing business in the Philippines.

Anacleta requested a PHP 20,000 loan through NWTF to buy fishing nets and other equipment for fishing.

Anacleta has been in this business for 15 years now, and earns additional income from a variety store.

In the future, Anacleta would like to save enough to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy fishing nets and other equipment for fishing

loans.name: Marie

texts.fr: Marie est âgée de 25 ans et est mariée à Mathias un coiffeur. Le couple a un  enfant, qui n’est pas encore en âge de scolarisation et qui est à leur charge. Marie et son mari vivent dans la même maison avec leur enfant.  Marie a très peu fréquenté l’école, mais a appris la coiffure, activité qu’elle exerce depuis neuf ans environs. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et assurer les diverses charges de sa famille, parallèlement à son métier de coiffure, Marie vend des mèches  et des produits pour cheveux dans son atelier et par le système de la distribution. Marie s’approvisionne dans l’un des marchés du Bénin. Dans le but de renforcer son activité par l’augmentation du stock de ses produits à l’approche des fêtes de fin d’année, Marie sollicite auprès de ALIDé un troisième crédit. Les deux premiers crédits reçus par Marie ont été bien remboursés.
texts.en: Marie is twenty-five years old and is married to Mathias, a hairdresser. The couple has a child who has not yet reached school age and is in their care. Marie and her husband live in the same house with their child. Marie did not attend much school, but learned hairdressing, an occupation that she has practiced for around nine years. To meet her needs and see to the various needs of her family, at the same time as her profession as a hairdresser, Marie sells hair extensions and hair products in her shop and through a distribution system. Marie stocks up in one of Benin's markets. With the goal of increasing her activity by augmenting the stock of her products as the end of the year festivals approach, Marie seeks a third loan through Alidé. The first two loans received by Marie have been paid back.

loans.use: To buy hair extensions and hair products

loans.name: Simana W.g A Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Simana W. Group A in Western Kenya! Judith is the facilitator of Simana W. group A. This  group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Judith takes care of one child at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Judith had a very good maize yield harvesting 5 bags on 1/2 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Judith was only able to harvest 2 bags of maize on 1/2 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Judith and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Judith will educate her child, ensure food security and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Simana W group A will each plant  between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Akbari's Group

texts.en:
Akbari is 41 years old and spends her time staying at home and doing her household responsibilities. Her husband sells buffaloes and milk to his community clients for profit. Akbari provides full support to her husband and takes care of the cattle by keeping their living place clean and giving them good quality food. She has given birth to 6 children. Her eldest son is 15 years old and helps his father to operate his business.

Akbari has applied for a loan from Kiva's partner Asasah for the further expansion of her husband’s business. With the loan, he will buy another buffalo, which he will sell for profit. He is operating his business for the past many years and Akbari is confident that an investment will bring more profits to him and will improve the living conditions of her family. 

Note: "In the picture, the lady holding the passbook called Asasah passbook is Akbari".

loans.use: to buy a buffalo for her livestock business.

loans.name: Kisarawe Group

texts.en:
Basilia, who is in her mid-40s, is married and has four children — two of whom are going to school. She has been running a clothing business for four years now. She works from 10 AM to 2 PM and is able to make a fair monthly profit.

This will be her third loan from Tujijenge Tanzania. She used the previous loans to pay school fees and home expenses, as well as to expand her clothing business. She has paid back all of her loans successfully. She wants a loan to increase her clothing stock. Her dream is to one day be able to buy a plot of land and to own a car.

She will share this loan with her loan group "Kisarawe," which has a total of 17 members who will hold each other accountable in paying back their loans.

loans.use: to increase her clothing stock.

loans.name: Isanjilo Group

texts.en:
Greetings from the Isanjilo Group in Western Kenya! Wanyama is the facilitator of Isanjilo group. This group joined One Acre Fund in 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. 

Wanyama takes care of three children at home. He joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Wanyama had an excellent maize yield harvesting six bags on half an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Wanyama was only able to harvest three bags of maize on that land. 

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Wanyama and his group during Kenya's next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs such as fertilizer and seed is part of One Acre Fund's integrated agriculture package, which also includes training, credit, and insurance. 

With the income from maize sales, Wanyama will educate his children, ensure food security and invest in livestock rearing. In 2012, the members of Isanjilo group will each plant between one half and one acre of maize.

loans.use: To buy farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita is a 27-year-old, married businesswoman. She did not graduate from college due to early marriage. According to her, she settled for marriage at the age of 24. She is thankful because her husband is supportive of her decisions in life. The couple are blessed with two children.

Teresita has been managing her rice farming business for almost seven years and her variety store for three years. She grows rice on her three hectares of rice fields. Teresita is aiming to improve the rice field she manages so that she can provide for her family's needs. The income generated from her farming business goes to her obligations to traders with higher interest. Some of it is also utilized for their daily needs and electric bill payments. With the situation she faces nowadays, she is in need of additional working capital. So, Teresita is asking for a loan in the amount of P45,000 which she will use to purchase fertilizer, herbicides, and insecticides for her farming business. Using the loan, she can make her rice field more productive.

Teresita says that the key is to strive for the best to obtain success in life and manage the hardships in business. She also plans to increase sales at her variety store so that she can support her family's needs and save for her children's future and for emergency purposes.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, herbicides, and insecticides for farming.

loans.name: Beatha

texts.en:
Beatha is 26 years old and is married with one child who is four years old.  She has had a sewing business for five years, and works every day from 8 a.m. until 9 p.m.

Beatha has requested a loan from Kiva field partner Vision Finance Company in order to purchase an additional sewing machine. If she is able to realize additonal profit as a result of this loan, Beatha hopes to open up other outlets of her business in the area.

loans.use: to buy an additional sewing machine

loans.name: Elvia

texts.en:
Elvia is 53 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 3 children. 
Elvia is peddling & selling peanut delicacies like candies . She has had this business for 10 years. She has requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy peanuts for sell.
Elvia has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Elvia hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy peanuts for sale

loans.name: Maria De Jesus

texts.en:
ENGLISH

Two years ago Maria de Jesus decided to sell shoes to help with the home expenses of her family. She thought that this activity was very practical because by doing it, she does not neglect her home and could take care of her sons. Years before she sold jewelry, but she left this business because she had to travel a lot to Guadalajara, Jalisco which is about 10 hours to Monterrey by bus and this was so difficult for her. Also she spent money in travel expenses so it was not advantageous. As she had a portfolio of clients already, she decided to find something different with demand and available to purchase in her city as well, so Maria de Jesus found her actual business of selling shoes and plastic articles by catalogue. She needs a loan for $850 and is asking for 6 months to repay the loan, because this time her shoe sales will increase for school season and for this reason she needs to invest in merchandise. She comments that this business makes her feel free and independent because her earnings are good and it is not necessary to request money from her husband for her basic expenses (and two of her three sons are in the university). She works for awhile every afternoon and every weekend she dedicates more time. She feels very happy with her achievements and Maria de Jesus does not discard the possibility of one day getting to have her own center of distribution.

SPANISH

Hace 2 años María de Jesús, decidió ponerse a vender calzado para ayudar con los gastos del hogar, consideraba que era una actividad muy práctica, ya que con ella no descuidaría su casa y el cuidado de sus hijos. Antes vendía joyería, pero dejo este negocio porque tenía que viajar a la ciudad de Guadalajara, Jalisco a más de 10 horas de distancia para traer la mercancía, y esto se le dificultaba mucho, además de tener que invertir en los gastos de viaje, y ya no le resultaba tan ventajoso. Como ya contaba con una cartera de clientes, decidió buscar algo que también tuviese demanda, pero que pudiese comprar en la misma ciudad, fue así como dio con la venta de calzado y vasijas de plástico, las cuales vende por catálogo y surte el pedido conforme lo demandan sus clientes. Esta solicitando un préstamo de $9,000 a 6 meses, pues en calzado se le han incrementado las ventas con motivo del regreso a clases de los niños, por lo que necesita invertir en mercancía. Ella comenta que gracias al negocio, se siente independiente, pues las ganancias son buenas y no necesita estar pidiendo dinero a su esposo para cubrir sus gastos más básicos. Ya que 2 de sus 3 hijos están estudiando en la universidad. Su negocio lo atiende un rato por las tardes y los fines de semana, que es cuando le dedica mayor tiempo. Se siente satisfecha con lo que esta logrando y no descarta la posibilidad de llegar a tener su propio centro de distribución bien establecido.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise for her business

loans.name: Tamara

texts.en: Tamara O. has kept bees for honey production for the last 25 years. She lives in the Gegeli village in the Agsu region with her husband and six children. She hopes to purchase more equipment to expand her business.

loans.use: to expand her business

loans.name: Jahnitta

texts.en: Jahnitta is a small business operator who sells pancakes to earn a living. She is married with six children, and she believes that she is one of the best pancake makers in her country. However, pancakes in Samoa are not the S. as the flat ones seen on breakfast tables in other places. Samoan pancakes are round, ball-like delicacies that are enjoyed by those who cannot afford to buy breads for a large family. The pancakes are less expensive and a small amount of money can buy pancakes for eight people. Jahnitta makes her pancakes in her home and sells to families and school children. She is requesting a loan so she can produce more and increase her income.

loans.use: To purchase oil, flour, bananas, and yeast

loans.name: Petrona

texts.es:
Mrs. Petrona is 57 years old and opened her shop in 1997. Her intentions at the time were to help out her husband, who is a public transportation chaufferu, as well as proviD. for her four sons who are close to entering University, which is costly. Today, the business functions very well, and there are plans of expanding it. The expansion would serve to pay for education costs as well as improving their quality of life.

She came to us at a time when the economy of her country is not at its best. She has counted on her good luck, and has been able to expand her business to its current state. Now she is looking to greatly increase the diversity of articles and would like to also sell toys, children's clothing, souvenirs and jewelry as there is a great demand for this from her current and potential clients.

Translated from Spanish by Chloé Tuot, a Kiva Volunteer.

La Sra. Petrona D. 57 años abrió su despensa en el año 1997. La intención era ayudar a su marido, que es chofer D. una linea D. transporte público, pues contaba con 4 hijos quienes estaban por iniciar la carrera Universitaria cuyo costo fue y sigue siendo muy elevado. Hoy día el negocio funciona muy bien, inclusive con perspectivas D. crecimiento que contribuyan no solo a cubrir gastos D. educación sino para tener una mejor calidad D. vida. Ella nos cuenta que aunque la economía del país no se encuentra en su mejor momento, ella ha contado con una suerte extraordinaria, pues ha visto crecer su negocio a pasos agigantados, ahora desea ampliar más la diversidad D. sus mercaderías y desea vender también artículos D. mercería, regalos, ropa para niños, souvenirs y bijuterie pues existe una gran demanda D. parte D. sus clientes actuales y potenciales futuros clientes.

loans.use: Purchasing toys, souvenirs, children's clothing and jewelry

loans.name: Ana Maria

texts.es:
Hello. My name is Ana Maria. I am the single mother of three and for a number of years I have supported my family selling corn-on-the-cob and tamales. I am proud to say they are all in school and I hope to give them the means to get ahead.

Translated by a Kiva volunteer.

Hola mi nombre es Ana Maria, cuento con un pequeño negocio de venta de elotes y nacatamales ( productos para el consumo Humano), tengo varios años de dedicarme a este tipo de actividad, la que me genera ingresos para cubrir los gastos familiares y otros compromisos, soy madre soltera y tengo 3 hijos los que gracias a Dios estan estudiando y que con las utilidades que me genera este negocio puedo cubrir estos gastos y sacar adelante a mis hijos.

loans.use: To buy corn, lard, firewood and charcoal.

loans.name: Louisette

texts.en: Louisette B. is a 28-year-old single mother. She sells textiles and fashion clothing in Belleville's market (southern area of Abidjan). She has more than 7 years work experience in dealing in the textiles sector in Abidjan. Louisette lives with her 9-year-old  daughter who is in primary school downtown. Louisette imports some of her products from neighboring Ghana, where she travels regularly for business. Louisette joined the AE&I microcredit program early in 2005 when she received her first loan. She is a very good performer and has been able to reimburse all her loans in good manner.

loans.use: Louisette Bleoussi will use the loan to purchase clothing

loans.name: Mikayil

texts.en: Mikayil M. is a 46-year-old farmer. He lives with his wife and one daughter in the southern part of Azerbaijan, in Bilasuvar region. Mikayil is an internally displaced person from occupied Jabrail region who fled to Bilasuvar during the Azerbaijani-Armenian conflict in 1993. He keeps poultry and sells it to the local bazaar traders and local people. His daughter is ten years old and she likes to help her father with poultry. Selling poultry is only  financial source in Mikayil`s family and nowadays, when prices are so high, it is not enough for a normal life. Mikayil is going to expand his business and purchase one calf, five sheep and fodder for winter. He applied to Aqroinvest CU for 700 USD with a repayment term of 15 months. The estimated cost for one calf is 300 USD, for sheep are 60 USD and 100 USD for fodder.

loans.use: Going to purchase one calf, five sheep and fodder

loans.name: Manzooran

texts.en: “I have seven children and live in a small town called Vehari with my family, including my husband and seven children. I have five boys and two girls. My husband and I have been operating a bedding and bangles business for the past three years. We buy both bed sheets and bangles from the city in bulk and sell them at a profit door-to-door in our town and surrounding villages. We require a loan of US$ 150 to purchase stock in bulk. We purchase each piece for US$ 6 and sell for US$ 10 and believe that with the profits we will be able to return the loan.”

loans.use: Purchase stock of bedding and bangles to retail door-to-door

loans.name: Mercedes Concepción

texts.es:
Mercedes Concepcion F. V. owns a sewing workshop. From the time she was a young girl she has shown skill for this work, and today serves as a seamstress in the city of Chinandega. Her business began when her husband went out of work and support ran out for their children, so she began looking for ways to buy a sewing machine so she could work as a seamstress.

With little savings she decided to put a sign outside of her home with the phrase "all types of dresses made to order". This is how she really began to work, by attracting the attention of various people who have since become her customers.

Mercedes has been working with CEPRODEL for 4 years and is very happy with the loans because they have been provided in a timely manner, which in turn have helped her meet the needs of her business and satisfy her customers. She has a record of 7 loans with CEPRODEL.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Gould, Kiva volunteer.

Mercedes Concepción F. V. es una dama que posee el negocio de taller de costura, ella desde muy niña ha demostrado la habilidad para esta labor y hoy en día se desempeña como costurera en la ciudad de Chinandega específicamente en Chichigalpa. Su negocio lo comienza cuando su esposo queda sin trabajo y por el apoyo que debía de dar a sus hijos, busca la manera de cómo adquirir su maquina para realizar sus trabajos de costurera.

Con los pocos ahorros que ella posee decide poner un rotulo en las afueras de su local con la frase “se hacen vestidos de todo tipo” es a si que ella comienza a trabajar por si sola captando la atención de varias personas que posteriormenente se convirtieron en sus clientes.

Mercedes trabaja con CEPRODEL desde hace 4 años y se siente muy satisfecha con los créditos otorgados ya que se los han brindado en el momento oportuno, ayudando a sí a suplir las necesidades del negocio y poder satisfacer a los clientes con los pedidos que le hacen, ella tiene un record de 7 créditos.

loans.use: To purchase threads, fabrics and supplies for her shop. (Compra de hilos, bobinas, telas)

loans.name: Mujeres Unidas Por El Progresso, Group 1

texts.en:
Constancia is an ambitious woman with a great sense of humor and vibrant personality. She lives in La Viara, a small village in Puerto Plata, with her husband and two children. You would never know she is 42 years old since she active, energetic, and young-spirited. When she is not working she enjoys spending time with her family and watching television. Although rice and beans are the typical Dominican food, she informed us that vegetables were her favorite food and they help keep her healthy.

Constancia sells clothing from her house and also has a large clientele that comes to her home for manicures. This is her second loan and she wants to use it to purchase a larger inventory of clothing and some new supplies for her manicure business. A lot of her materials are worn and she needs to replace them in order to do continue doing nails.

On behalf of everyone here at Esperanza International, and from Constancia herself, we thank you for your support with this business loan!

loans.use: to purchase clothing and personal care products

loans.name: Sili 2 Centre - Group 1

texts.en:
The village of Sili on Savaii Island is one of the well-endowed villages in terms of natural resources.  It has very rich soil, with a large number of springs and creeks which serve as natural irrigation for farms located at the foot of the mountain ranges. Most of the households in Sili village farm taro, bananas and vegetables. They sell their products in the capital town of Salelologa, which is about 40 kilometers from the village. The village learned about SPBD through the radio talk-back shows and from a meeting SPBD staff made with a village chief.   After the successful training of the first loan group in Sili village, more women became interested in the SPBD savings and loan program.  The village chief has convened the village council, endorsed the SPBD program and encouraged women in the village to join. They are now thinking of putting up a string of stalls by the roadside so that women sell their produce to passersby as an alternative to going to the Salelologa market.

Sili 2 group will be using their loans for the following purposes:


Eseta L. (45, married, 2 children): purchase 2 bush knives, 2 knife filings (sharpeners), spades, workers to cultivate and sell taro, tuamu and bananas.  

Lina I. (60, widow, 8 children): purchase a knife, spade, filing, 3 bush knives and other farming equipment to grow and sell taro, tuamu and yams. 

P. Komisi (45, widow, 2 children): purchase a bush knife, filing, spade and other farming equipment to cultivate and sell popcorn, taro and yams. 

Ruta T. (50, married, 6 children): purchase 2 knives, a pick, a filing, a rake and other farming equipment to grow and sell taro and bananas. 

Sau T. (48, married, 4 children): purchase 5 bush knives, a weed killing sprayer and workers to grow and sell taro and yams. 

Silifu T. (38, married, 2 children): purchase 3 bush knives, a spade, a filing and other farming equipment to grow and sell taro, bananas, and tuamu. 

Sulesa I. (36, married, 1 child) purchase 2 knives, a filing, a wheel barrow, a spade and a weed killing sprayer to cultivate and sell taro and bananas. 

Toaiga A. (43, married, 7 children) purchase a bush knife, filing, spade and other farming equipment to grow and sell taro and bananas.  

Tofe A. (24, married, 2 children) purchase 2 knives, 2 filings, boots, a weed killing sprayer to cultivate and sell taro and bananas.

loans.use: Purchase of bush knives, spades, knife filings, etc…

loans.name: Akumu Mary, Bugolo Group

texts.en:
People are really struggling to better their standards of living and this is what Mary A., a member of the Bugolo Lending Group, is going through but it’s paying. She sells "mukene" (a small silvery fish) wholesale, meaning she works hand-in-hand with her husband in fishing. Though at times she stays behind to dry up the fish and deal with customers.

Some of her group members are her customers in a business she has been running for five years. She sells a basin of the fish for $3.00 and on a good day she can sell over 50 basins. Really, fishing is best for men but, to Mary, this is business. She needs a loan to be able to buy another boat and a fishing net, as well as build a house in the plot they bought previously. She is so grateful for the group loans.

loans.use: Mary would buy another boat and a fishing net with her part of this group loan

loans.name: Asha

texts.en:
Mrs. Asha Rawot lives in the town of Bagdol, in the Lalitpur region of Nepal. Most people in this region run small businesses such as grocery stores, small hotels and stationery stores.

Mrs. Maharjan is a widow who lives with her two sons. Three years ago, her husband, Mr. Tilak Rawot died, giving her sole responsibility for her family . Both of her sons are in school, one in the 10th grade and the other in the 6th.

Mrs. Rawot opened a small hotel three years ago. She also runs a shop where she sells different types of Nepali food, along with tea and coffee. She has applied for a $225 loan to buy food supplies for this business.

loans.use: To  purchase food for her business.

loans.name: Tet

texts.en: Tet N. lives in Phnom Penh, Cambodia, and helps to support her family by running an apartment rental business out of her home, renting additional bedrooms to garment workers. She is applying for a loan of $1,200 in order to renovate her house to better increase her rental business. Mrs. Tet has two children, one of whom is married and contributes to the family income through pickle sales. The other child is a student at a local school. Mrs. Tet is pictured here with her daughter. She is a client of CREDIT MFI, a Cambodian Microfinance company that is a division of the international NGO World Relief.

loans.use: To renovate her house for rental purposes

loans.name: Marhamat

texts.en:
Marhamat N. is 60 years old. She is a widow and has eight adult and independent children. Marhamat has been working the land for 27 years already. Her younger son helps Marhamat with the business. On her plot of land, she grows such vegetables as tomatoes, cucumbers, pumpkins, maize, and other vegetables according to the season. Over the years of her activity Marhamat has acquired the knowledge and skills required for the business. For instance, she knows how to store vegetables so that they keep their marketable condition and do not to lose their taste and useful properties.

Each year Marhamat grows enough for family consumption and for selling. The business is their main source of income and even while generating a stable income, it requires considerable funding. Today Marhamat is requesting US$ 300 for a term of 7 months. Marhamat plans to spend the loan purchasing seeds and mineral fertilizer for growing vegetables. She would like to thank all who support her and promises to manage the loan correctly.

loans.use: Purchasing of  seeds and mineral fertilizer

loans.name: Zahra

texts.en:
Zahra is 45 years old. She is married and she has 6 children aged between 9 and 20. She also takes care of a 65-year-old person. She has been running a small shop since 2000. Every day, she works from 7 AM to 10 PM at her business and she can earn a monthly profit of about $250 from her sales.

Zahra now hopes for a loan to increase her stock.

loans.use: To increase her stock

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To restock her grocery store in order to make it more profitable.

loans.name: Maysa

texts.en: Maysa is 27 years old and owns a small mobile phone shop in Beirut. She has requested a loan of $800 from A. Majmoua to purchase a new supply of modern cellular phones and accessories. Maysa is a shrewd businesswoman and is confident that this loan will allow her to effectively diversify her product offerings, and by so doing, attract a broader range of clients. Maysa is grateful for the opportunity provided to her by Kiva and A. Majmoua.

loans.use: To purchase a new stock of mobile phones for Maysaa's shop.

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en:
Rebecca M., who is married with three children, has been selling used clothing at the market place in Cape Coast since 2002. She uses her income to pay for the children's school fees and the utility bills. Her husband is a commercial driver.

Rebecca is requesting a loan to increase the quantity of used clothing she sells to meet increased demand. She plans to save for future use the increased profits that will result from her expanded business.

loans.use: To increase the quantity of used clothing she sells to meet increased demand.

loans.name: Genesis Group

texts.es:
hola nosotros somos el grupo GENESIS estamos ubicados en el municipio de Danli, nosotros tenemos mucho tiempo de conocernos y siempre hemos trabajado juntos ya que somos vecinos, nuestro grupo esta solicitando un credito para adquirir materia prima y compra de mercaderia para la venta, este credito sera de mucha importancia para nosotros, nuestro grupo se forma de esta manera:
Santos Cristina L.: soy la coordinadora del grupo me dedico a la venta de productos de consumo popular y venta de repuestos de bicicletas, tengo 4 años de dedicarme a esta activiidad.
Santos Julian L.: el se dedica a la compra y venta de granos basicos desde hace 4 años, con los ingresos que el recibe de esta actividad le permiten cumplir con los gastos personales, el es un hombre soltero y con muchos deseos de superacion, el le apoya a sus padres con los gastos del hogar.
Nohemi del Carmen R.: la actividad de ella es la venta de cosmeticos, con este negocio ella ayuda a su familia a salir adelante con los gastos del hogar.
todos necesitamos este credito para salir adelante, y como es espoca de navidad las ventas son buenas y por eso es que necesitamos comprar mas producto para poder cubrir con las necesidades de todos nuestros clientes.
texts.en:
Hi, we are the GENESIS group, located in the town of Danli. We've had a lot of time to get to know each other and we've always worked together because we're neighbors. Our group is asking for a loan to acquire raw materials and commodities to sell. This loan is very important to us. Our group is organized as follows:

Santos Cristina L.: I am the coordinator of the group. I sell popular consumer goods and bicycle parts, and have done so for four years.

Santos Julian L.: He has bought and sold basic grains for the past four years, and he uses his earnings to cover his personal expenses. He is a single man with many aspirations, who helps his parents with their household expenses.

Nohemi del Carmen R.: She sells cosmetics, and with this business helps her family pay off their household expenses.

We all need this loan to succeed. With the Christmas season upon us, sales are good and we need to buy more products to meet all our customers' needs.

Translated from Spanish by Trisha Bury, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase commodities

loans.name: Sarela

texts.es: Sarela tiene 24 años, es madre de dos hijos en edad escolar, vive con su conviviente quien la ayuda en su trabajo. Ella se dedica a la venta de pescado en un puesto del mercado, complementado con  productos de primera necesidad, este trabajo lo viene realizando desde hace 5  años y lo que le gusta es dar una buena atención a sus clientes quienes son el factor principal en su negocio. Además le es rentable porque cuenta con una clientela selecta y se encuentra ubicada en un buen lugar, le va muy bien. Es la tercera vez que solicita un préstamo con MFP. Con este dinero mandará a construir un kiosco para su puesto de venta, y así dar una mejor acogida a sus clientes.
texts.en:
Sarela is a 24-year-old mother with two school age children. She lives with her partner, who helps out with her business. She sells fish and basic need items in a market stand. She has been in business for 5 years, and what she likes about her job is providing excellent service to her customers, who are essential for her business. Furthermore, her business is lucrative because it is located in an optimal place and because she has a solid clientele; her business is prospering. This is the third time that she requests a loan from MFP. With this money, she will have a kiosk made so that she can better welcome her customers.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Build a kiosk for her business

loans.name: Jiguitougou (L’Espoir) Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Jiguitougou  est un regroupement de quatre femmes du   quartier medina-koura de la ville de Koutiala(troisième région administrative de la république du Mali) qui sont  des voisines de longue date. Elles ont en moyenne 35 ans, mariées et mères d’au moins 4 enfants chacune. 
Elles mènent essentiellement les activités de coiffure (tresses) et la vente de mèches. Le service des femmes du groupe Jiguitougou est très apprécié sollicité par les grandes dames de la ville de Koutiala et elles ont de l’expérience dans leur secteur d’activité et évoluent avec  la mode.
Dans l’objectif d’augmenter la taille de leurs activités, les membres ont intégré le programme  crédit de Soro Yiriwaso depuis 5 ans. Ces femmes du groupe Jiguitougou sont à leurs  neuvième prêts solidaires après avoir remboursé sans difficulté les huit premiers. 
Le prêt actuel sera utilisé pour acheter des cartons de mèches à Lomé et les revendre aux clientes qui viennent se tresser et à d’autres très généralement au comptant mais quelques fois à crédit.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 160 000 CFA. Ce bénéfice sera utilisé pour rembourser les intérêts du prêt et contribuer dans la prise en charge des dépenses courantes de la famille. Dans l’avenir, le groupe Jiguitougou ambitionne d’ouvrir des  boutiques de luxe beauté  et diversifier  leurs activités.
texts.en:
The Jiguitougou group comprises four women living in the Medina-Koura quarter (city of Koutiala, third administrative region of the Republic of Mali), who have been neighbors for a long time. They are married and are, on average 35 years old, and the mother of at least four children each. Their businesses consist mainly in hairdressing (braiding) and selling hair extensions. Their services are very much appreciated and sought-after by the upper-class women of the city of Koutiala. They have a lot of experience in their field, and follow the trends. In view of expanding their businesses, the members of the group joined the loan program of Soro Yiriwaso five years ago. These women are now seeking their ninth solidarity loan, after having repaid the first eight without problems. The new loan will be used to buy boxes of hair extensions in Lomé, and to resell them to customers who are getting their hair braided, and to others, usually for cash but sometimes also on credit. With this new loan, they intend to turn an average profit of XOF 160'000 (ca US$ 320). This profit will be used to repay the loan and to help with the daily family expenses. In the future, the Jiguitougou group ambitions to open luxury beauty shops and to diversify their businesses.

Translated from French by Patrick Stadelmann, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell hair extensions

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en: Joyce S., married with three children, received schooling through junior high. Married to a trader, Joyce has sold used clothing at Abura for the past three years, using her income to pay for house-keeping expenses since her husband takes care of the family’s financial needs. Joyce will use the loan as additional capital to increase the sale of fried fish to meet the increase in demand by her customers. With the new profits from her expanded business, Joyce plans to reinvest back for the expansion of her trade.

loans.use: Joyce will use the loan to purchase as additional capital to enable her increase the sale of fried fish to meet the increase in demand by her costumers.

loans.name: Zary

texts.es:
La señora Zary V. R., pertenece al Banco Comunal “Amistad y Paz”, vive en el Jr. La Merced Nº 268, Distrito de Juanjui, Departamento de San Martín. Es conviviente, tiene 26 años y es madre de 2 hijos, uno que todavía depende de ella. 

Con el primer préstamo de S/. 300.00, empezó vendiendo sus marcianos, gaseosas y hielos. Tiene 03 años trabajando con el Banco. En la actualidad se dedica a la Venta de Abarrotes, en su negocio que  se encuentra ubicado en su misma casa.

Con el préstamo de S/1,500.00 que cancelará a plazo de 06  meses, desea invertirlo, ampliando e implementando su negocio, y comprar arroz y azúcar en sacos, como también útiles escolares, cuadernos en cientos, lapiceros, borradores, papel de escritorio, para atender la actual demanda de sus clientes.   

Ella, toma las decisiones en las ganancias de su negocio, se siente tranquila y deseosa de seguir con sus proyectos. 

Zary, manifiesta su agradecimiento a Manuela Ramos por permitirle crecer como empresaria y Mujer.
texts.en:
Zary V. R. is a member of the Amistad y Paz (Friendship and Peace) Village Bank. She lives in the Juanjui District in the Department of San Martín. She is 26, has a common law husband, and is the mother of two children, one of whom is still dependent. With her first loan, for 300 soles, she began selling marcianos (popsicles), soft drinks and ice. She has been working with the Village Bank for three years. Currently she earns her living selling groceries from her own house. She would like to invest her loan of 1,500 soles, which she will pay back in 6 months, in building and expanding her business. She will buy rice and sacks of sugar, as well as school supplies, including notebooks in bulk, pens, erasers, and office paper to meet her customers' demands. Zary makes her own decisions regarding her business income. She feels at peace and is eager to move ahead with her projects. She is grateful to Manuela Ramos for letting her grow as both a businessperson and a woman.

Translated from Spanish by Jill Heske, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy rice, sugar, and school supplies, including notebooks, pens, and erasers for her business.

loans.name: Mamlakat

texts.ru: Бобоева Мамлакат проживает в районе Варзоб. Возраст 32 года, разведена и одна воспитывает пятерых детей. Занимается торговлей на рынке  Варзоба. Торгует женским бельем и детской одеждой. Заниается этим бизнесом уже пять лет. Доход составляет около 700 сомони в месяц. Обратилась за кредитом для того, чтобы  увеличить товарооборот и завезти сезонный товар.Погасить кредит сможет в течение 12 месяцев.
texts.en:
Mamlakat B. lives in the Varzob area. She is 32 years old, is divorced and is raising five children by herself. She is a saleswoman at the Varzob market. She sells women’s lingerie and children’s clothing. Mamlakat has been in this business for five years now. She earns around 700 somoni per month. She has turned to us for a loan in order to increase her turnover and purchase seasonal products.

Translated from Russian by Sabina Holzman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase seasonal clothing

loans.name: Manuela

texts.es: Manuela tiene 31 años, es profesora de profesión, y madre soltera, vive con su único hijo en la casa de su tía. Desde hace un año cría pollos en un pequeño corral que mandó a construir en un espacio del terreno de su tía, Manuela también ejerce como profesora en un centro educativo de su localidad. Es importante que siempre esté atenta al desarrollo de sus animales, ya que depende de ello, el precio que pueda obtener al venderlos. Una vez que están con el debido peso y tamaño, los sacrifica, limpia, y generalmente los vende listos para ser preparados a la parrilla. La rentabilidad de este negocio está en que cada 40 días cada pollo ya obtuvo el tamaño necesario para su venta. Este es su segundo préstamo con MFP, y le gusta trabajar con su banco comunal porque sus integrantes son coordinados y no hay problemas con las fechas de pago. Con el dinero que viene solicitando comprará pollos bebé y alimento necesario para su crianza.
texts.en:
Manuela is a 31-year old teacher (by profession) who is single and lives with her only son in her aunt's house. For the last year, she has raised chickens in a small corral built on her aunt's property. Manuela also teaches at an educational center in her neighborhood.
